claim: Paris is the capital of France

supporting.text: The French Constitution designates Paris as the capital of France.

attacks.text: The French Constitution designates Paris as the capital of France.
The French Constitution has been amended in the past, and future amendments could theoretically change the capital.
Constitutional amendments regarding the capital are highly unlikely due to historical and cultural significance of Paris.
During WWII, the Vichy regime temporarily moved the de facto capital to Vichy, showing that the constitutional designation can be overridden in practice.
The Vichy regime was an exceptional wartime circumstance not representative of normal constitutional order, and Paris remained the de jure capital throughout.

supporting.text: All major government institutions, including the National Assembly and the Presidency, are located in Paris.

attacks.text: All major government institutions, including the National Assembly and the Presidency, are located in Paris.
Some government institutions, such as the Constitutional Council, have offices outside Paris.
The Constitutional Council's primary functions and official seat remain in Paris, with only minor administrative offices elsewhere.
Historical capitals like Versailles temporarily held government functions, suggesting Paris's role isn't absolute.
Versailles was never formally designated as France's capital, and all constitutional documents recognize Paris as the sole capital.

supporting.text: Historical records consistently identify Paris as the capital since the Middle Ages.

attacks.text: Historical records consistently identify Paris as the capital since the Middle Ages.
During the German occupation in WWII, Vichy was the de facto capital of France.
Vichy's status was not internationally recognized, and Paris remained the official capital despite occupation.
The Carolingian Empire had multiple capitals, including Aachen, challenging Paris's uninterrupted status.
The Carolingian Empire predates the modern French state, and Paris's role as capital is undisputed in the post-medieval period.

supporting.text: International organizations and diplomatic missions recognize Paris as the capital of France.

attacks.text: International organizations and diplomatic missions recognize Paris as the capital of France.
Some unrecognized states or non-state entities may dispute Paris as the capital of France for political reasons.
The international community overwhelmingly recognizes Paris as the capital, making such disputes irrelevant in practice.

supporting.text: Geopolitical maps and atlases universally label Paris as the capital of France.

attacks.text: Geopolitical maps and atlases universally label Paris as the capital of France.
Some historical maps from the Vichy France period (1940-1944) labeled Vichy as the de facto capital, not Paris.
The Vichy government was never internationally recognized as the legitimate government of France, and Paris remained the official capital even during occupation.
Some alternative geography movements challenge conventional capital designations as colonial constructs.
The overwhelming consensus in international law and diplomatic practice recognizes Paris as France's capital without controversy.

supporting.text: The administrative and political functions of the country are centralized in Paris.

attacks.text: The administrative and political functions of the country are centralized in Paris.
Some administrative functions are decentralized to other cities like Lyon or Marseille.
Decentralized functions are minor compared to the core political and administrative roles still held by Paris.
